DIV1.P: FALSE SHAME: A COMEDY, IN FOUR ACTS, TRANSLATED FROM THE GERMAN OF KOTZEBUE.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED BY M. L. & W. A. DAVIS. FOR THOMAS S. ARDEN, No. 186, PEARL-STREET. 1800.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.

LIST.ITEM: MINNA, his Daughter by the first Wife.

DIV1.P: [The Scene is Unchanged, in the Counsellor's Garden—On one side of the Stage runs a Palisadoe fencing a Lawn—on the other side stand two lofty Trees, with the branches intertwined, shading a bank of turf.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. JOHN, upon a short ladder, clipping the hedge, humming a ditty and talking at intervals.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: LUXURIANT shoots:—here and every where: but they cannot every where be prun'd:—Ho! ho! could I but for once, with my sheers, go to work pell-mell a∣mong the rabble who are feasting here upon the fat of the land, snap! snap!—every cut should tell. (he sings, then pauses)—My poor master!—happiness was once in this garden a perennial ever-green—flourishing without labour in each nook: now have they hemm'd my good master within so close and thick a fence—that not a sun∣beam can penetrate a heval de frize: and the effects upon him is but too apparent, for he wastes away like a "viola maronalis" devoured by insects.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. EMMA crosses the Stage slowly, knitting, and as she passes says—Good morrow JOHN.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Good morrow, my heart's dear young lady; what so early risen; a thick dew is on the ground, and you will wet your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: The sun shone through my window, that at∣tracted me hither.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: (looking after her) a pretty flowret! that itself in the grass like a ripe strawberry. Heaven pre∣serve her from the ravenous jack-dws. Our Minna, is also good; ay, very good: but she fashions herself rather too much after her step-mother; and it may soon be said—he was good. (he sings and works.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Enter FRELON.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Bon jour, maitre Jean.

P.HI: (Paases; eyes him; smiles contemptuously and works on.)

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: (Approaches and cries) What ho!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: I say, bon jour, maitre Jean!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: And I say—go to the devil! I am an honest fellow, and must be spoken to in my mother tongue; do'st understand, Mounseer bon jour?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Master John is for ever grumbling.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: The Cuckoo is Maitre Jean—my name is John; keep your distance, with your French film-flams.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: The asses cry—Jahn! Jahn!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: So I hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Maitre Jean, sounds better.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: All passes current with you, if it doth but sound:—go your ways, Mounseer cling-clang, and leave me unshorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Sheep are shorn▪ but not bears.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Take heed of the bears paws.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Maitre Jean, avec permission, leave off sing∣ing—you have a cracked voice.

SP.SPEAKER: John
SP.P: Who hinders thee from taking thyself off?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: My master ordered me to wait for him here.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Then post thyself yonder among the young peas, that for once in thy life thou may'st be good for something.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Your jests are truly German.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Methinks, for German bread, thou may'st well digest German truisms.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: (fanning himself) It will be hot to day.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: There is mud in the pond, where thou may'st cool thyself.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Apropos: the pond must be filled up.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: (Surpris'd) What?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: I say the pond must anish.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Only let my master strike up a match with the daughter of the house, and we shall soon turn things topy turvy.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Your master—with Miss Minna?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the iscount is in a fair way to forget what he owes to his illustrious ancestors.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: So—but Miss Minna will scarcely forget what she owes to herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Mon ami, my master is accustomed to turn the heads of young girls.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Verily, they must be turned to endure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Respect—Maitre Jear—a word from me, and you fall under my master's displeasure.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Hey!—

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: At any rate—I have my doubts, her my master will continue your service.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: So!—

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: As to the kitchen garden, you may there perhaps understand your business:—but, mon ami, you want taste.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Your trees, hedges and tulips.—might pass in Holland.—but suit not our taste: we require strik∣ing prospects—improvistos—hermitages—mausolerms.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Now, have I enough of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: You are old, mon ami; have seen very little of the beautiful; il saut lui passer son ignorance; you may be welcome to continue here as under-gardner; but we shall engage a Frenchman—a sane pareil, ah! maitre Jear—you may then become a pupil.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I! become a pulpil!

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: What is now undermost—he will make up∣ermost;—he will improve the muddy pool in Dian's ath—and the down-falling forcing-house—into a Chi∣nese Kiosk.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Kiosk! Thou contemptible gasconader
SP.STAGE: (he seizes a water engine, and waters Frelon's legs.

SP.P: Maitre Jean, Maitre Jean,—what means all this!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Dianna's bath—Monscer bonjour!

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: I say, let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: If it does not please thee—why,—crawl into the Kiosk—(he follows Frelon about the stage.).

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. The Privy Counsellor FLAXLAND and the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: John—what art thou doing?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I am rooting up weeds!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Dost not know, in whose service the fellow is?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: (half aside) O! yes! like master, like man.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: (Wiping his legs with his handkerchief) Maitre Jean loves fun.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Where is your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Most likely—yet at the ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (forcing a smile) Bravo!—That I call dan∣cing.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Towards day-break, he sent me away, and ordered me to wait for him here.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (With constrain'd indifference) the Viscount will doubtless attend my wife home.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: My master knows good breeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Was the ball well kept up.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: O! yes! your lady dances—comme un ange, & Mademoiselle Wilhelmine—comme un zephyr.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Was the company numerous?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: Your lady, was seated at midnight in a circle of the beau monde.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (Suppressing his uneasiness) I hope she will not take cold, in returning home?

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: She sent back the phaetor—Chevalier Hugel offered his carriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Hugel! is he in town?—I am glad of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frelon.
SP.P: He arrived last night in full gallop—dis∣mounted—and flew to the ball—ventre saint gris—maitre Jean has so drench'd me, that, by your leave, I must change my chaussure.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V. Counsellor FLAXLAND and JOHN.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Prithee tell me, John, why the trees, near the water, are festooned together?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: It is my lady's order—I was to strip the garden of laylook and gilder roses.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But wherefore all this preparation?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: How should I know?—she is to give a some∣thing—the puppy just hopp'd off—named it in French—Mounseer Rosat, the friseur, described it to me—it is called—ha! ha! ha!—a dancing breakfast; the cooks have been at work all night—and the maids beat∣ing chocolate.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (with constrain'd indifference) So!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ay, ay, for a couple of years there has been such a bustle in the garden, that the nightingales have quite deserted it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No matter good old man, if contentment here still builds her nest.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ay ay, contentment is a pretty bird, but, at times flies away like swallows.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Be not offended, my dear master, I am an old grey headed servant, who look'd anxiously on, when you were baptized—you grew up, but always lov'd to be a∣lone;—when the neighbous' children played, you some∣times, through good nature, mingled in their sports—but then you look'd just as you do now—though never austere—you understand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (Smiling) If neighbours' children had claims on my good nature—how much more my dear wife!—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: But often, what is easy to the lad, goes a∣gainst the grain for the man—the twig bends—the tree breaks—After peaceably and quietly jogging on in the same path for the fourth of a century, at the end of the way, we are not inclined to practice any side steps.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My wife is young; I am turn'd of forty, and therefore shou'd be doubly obliging; (with warmth) and she is moreover entitled to my fullest confidence—she is, indeed, an incomparable woman.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Mighty well—if madam would but leave me the garden in peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: How so—old one—what difficulties, have you to encounter?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ah! my dear master—the garden is my para∣dise—my father—God bless him—plann'd the garden—there was I born and bred—and a couple of years ex∣cepted—which, through love of the art, I pass'd in Holland—I have scarce moved a step from the gate—my hand prunes each fruit tree—and what my arms can now scarcely span—I remember a tender sapling—Be∣hind yon meadow is a grass plat—it is hardly noticed—by the garden wall stands a few birch trees—where in the evening I smoke my pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Methought—that a good word to your honour in my behalf—would get your leave to have me buried there.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: That shall be done, my honest fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ah! but who knows how long these birch trees may remain—Madam has it under consideration to pull down the wall, and to make a plantation in the mea∣dow, with a labyrinth intermixed with a bit of a corn∣field—a Parnassus—and I know not what—and my poor birch trees will stand in the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No one shall molest thy birch-trees.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: But who will care about such poor wood, when even these beautiful linden trees are not spared.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What linden trees.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: (pointing to the two trees twined together) Do you no longer know your nurslings?—you and Miss Phi∣lippina planted them on your good mother's birth-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: O! I full well remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: You were then both children, scarcely taller than this rose-bush—and when you had put the cuttings in the ground—you joined your hands over them, and kiss'd one another—your lady mother wept, and said to me, John, have a care of these suckers—this I have faithfully done—they are become a pair of stately trees; and must I now fell them?—no▪ I cannot do it—the hand would grow nerveless that attempted to lay an axe to these roots.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But who wishes thee to cut 'em down?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P:
Madam says—when one sits in the summer
house, these linden trees shut out the prospect of the village.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No matter, these lindens shall not be touch'd—I especially entrust them to thee, John.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Mighty well.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: It is the sole remembrance of my poor sister.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Alas! Yes!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My dear woman knew not of this.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Likely not: it was but yesterday she first men∣tioned it. I believe the flighty Mounseer puts these fan∣cies in her head—He was with her,—skipping and pirou∣etting—treading down here a cucumber, and there the ripe strawberries. He seems to stand high in madam's good graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (With keen sensibility) Do'st think so?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: He never leaves her side.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: He is thought to be an agreeable companion.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: To be sure, he can prattle—and so can his valet de chamber.—he already boasts of alliances.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (eager) what alliances?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I dare not even repeat them, for I do not be∣lieve a syllable of the gasconnade.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (aside) So; already the servants prattle, (going to speak, but restrains himself) Enough John: I disturb thee in thy work—I could not sleep: and thought to be the first in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: The first! oh! no: Miss Emma was here half an hour ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Emma! where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yonder she sits knitting—yonder, among the rose bushes.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (Calling to her) Good-morrow, Emma.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. EMMA, and the former.

P.HI: removes further down, clipping his hedge, and gra∣dually disappears in the back ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Good-morrow, my dear father, I did not know you were so early risen.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P:
Thy case was mine, and thy tiptoe tread was
needless;—what wilt thou give me to be the messenger of good tidings?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Give! you joke! To give you, would be only to give back—for have I not received all from you?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: From me!—nothing my child:—thou owest me only the roof, beneath which thou dwellest; every thing else, to the last penny, is repaid me, by my astonishing friend, from his small stipend.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: But can he also repay your fatherly affection?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: That, thou amply refundest—familiarizing to me the delightful idea of having two daughters—in∣deed, I could almost become jealous, by reflecting, that I must to day divide my strongest claims upon your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: To day!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Erlach is expected.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Expected! and to-day!—my deliverer!—my noble benefactor!—at length, after eight years: but, my dear father, will he certainly come?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: He writes so—as usual, in three laconic lines—the intelligence surprised me: for at the beginning of a campaign, Erlach is not accustomed to make visits.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Scarcely can I recal his figure—O! would he were he! I will meet him—which road must he take?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No one knows—my worthy Erlach seldom adds place or date to his letters:—do but read; "Thou wilt receive enclosed, Emma's pension—and next Tuesday, myself"—that is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Sure enough! only a word or two—but stampt with kindness—his times is too precious for writing—'tis devoted to action:—is it not so dear father? the hour is lost to him that doth not dedicate some good deed to eternity.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: The gentle Emma has caught enthusiasm, and it pleases me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: O! when he raised the wretched Emma from the mass of ruins—when he shared with her his trifle of pay—whenever I think of it, I cannot but weep. My whole heart is his.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: And deservedly; may'st thou succeed, dear girl, in curing him of his woman hatred! and, indeed, the more I conteraplate thee—the more rational and the more probable, do I consider this hope—what thinkest thou Emma?—thou knowest the disposition of the man—his form alone is forgotten—but that is noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: And were he as ugly as the slumbering poet—whom a queen kiss'd in passing—he only uttered the beautiful—Erlach does it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thy gratitude takes such a lofty flight, that her wings seem soaring to the regions of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: What is love—if not attracted by the good and beautiful?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou art not then disinclined? thou permittest me to indulge an association of ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You joke, my dear father, and amuse your∣self with my reveries—but do ou know, that your playfulness may cherish a romantic day-dream, that has long been sporting in my brain?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Well, my dear little American, let's hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: When, on a summer's eve, I steal from your gay circle to wander in the avenue of elms, then build I castles in the air—how to recompence my bene∣factor—to enliven his old days—but I am playing the fool with my talkativeness—and fortunately I just now perceive our ball visitors returning home: dearest father, you have discovered my soul unveil'd—but yonder gala beaux, shall not surprize me in deshabille.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: And do they come at last?—but not to me! a dejeune dansant engages them homeward.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII. MINNA, HUGEL, FLAXLAND.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Good-morrow, to thee, my sweet pappa, or should I not rather say, good night, and pillow my cheek to sleep?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Art Thou fatigued?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Oh dying!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Dear Hugel, I so much the more rejoice to see my good neighbour—as, at this season I dared not expect the pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: You are right, Sir—the country in spring, furnishes so much occupation—so much gratification—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And what a grateful, a respectful curtesy, must I make you; that you left all to a chance medley—to be my partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Could my company be of the least possible value▪ I might flatter myself to have deserved it.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Extreme diffidence borders on vanity—who could have thought, dear pappa, that this young Squire—who hitherto lurked in a corner, and looked on when other folks were capering, last night, at my high behest at length boldly resolved to stand with me the last couple in a contra dance, upon the express condition, only to hand up—and then to retire, if the figure seemed too intricate. I Consequently expected nothing less—than an awkward simpleton, weighing like lead upon my arm, and bungling through right and left—when lo! he foot∣ed it along with me like a pupil of Vestris. In the name of wonder—why have you hitherto seemed as if you were lame?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I never danced in a public ball-room; the townsmen enjoy a laugh against us rustics.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: False shame was the only failing I could ever discover in my young friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I have not yet finished pappa—he sat next me at supper—I filled him bumpers, and was very atten∣tive to him—whether inspired by wine, or my smiles—the dumb Squire Hugel became eloquent,—conversed so sensibly—and sported such engaging bon mots, that I almost forgot I was in the temple of folly. But in hea∣ven's name thou wonderful man! why, hitherto, hast thou been so sparing of thy words?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: because I am apt to utter some absurdities in large circles.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P:
For this very reason—we have large circles, that every one may play the fool with impunity—what in a select company, is becoming diffidence—would in the world be called false shame; there, your apparel must be splendid, and your discourse dazling: by ou
fire side, we require comfort from cloathing—and good sense from conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (Who for some moments seemed restless and un∣easy) Where did'st thou leave thy mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: She supposed you was still in bed—and hast∣ened to your chamber to awaken you with a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Was she alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Alone! O dear! as if one could shake off the Viscountess de Maillac—without telling him, to go to the devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: He was then with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Not precisely with her—but behind her—when they perceive pappa is not above, they will of course come down into the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Quite right; for lo! yonder they are. (his countenance brightens, and he hastens to meet his wife.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII. MRS. FLAXLAND VISCOUNT DE MAILLAC, and the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Nous voilla, Monsieur le Conseillere.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Good-morrow, my love—hast thou been well amused?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Tolerably, my dear—I met a couple of my youthful friends—whom I have not seen for an age; we laughed and prattled—they greet thee kindly—and beg thou wilt not be offended at their having so long detained me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Offended! what gives thee pleasure, makes me happy.

P.HI: Bravo, Monsieur, le Conseillere! vivent les maris raisonables.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Hast thou at all missed me, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My heart always misses thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Very gallant, quite a french tournure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Therefore, I will remain with thee, the whole day—I have invited some twenty friends—we will breakfast in the grove, and fancy ourselves in Pyrmont.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! bravo! Madame la Conseil∣lere has charming ideas.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (curtsies) My ideas are highly obilged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Faith, Mesdames—I entered Germany with very moderate expectations: I had imbibed a frightful idea of German ladies—it was said a girl of fifteen blushed, through timidity, in taking off her glove—and at table, thrust her hands under the plate—sitting by the side of a man of fashion, with a dumb and vacant countenance—or else, unmannerly laughing—grimacing—and whispering to her play-fellows:—a girl of eigh∣teen has ever tearful eyes—is plunged into an ocean of sensibility; affects a partiality, and construes rude∣ness to a stranger, into constancy to a lover: a woman of twenty, imagines she displays her virtue, in hanging back like a child, whenever a young man approaches her—and pouts if he utters any thing gallant: a woman of twenty-five—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Enough, Viscount—else we shall dis∣patch you to Hanover, to the man who has written a satirical book against our sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I will write an Encyclopedie against him, and should I ever return to my country—evil betide the prater who sports a bon mot upon the German ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And, as a reward, the German maidens should speedily convey you to the grave, as the female's poet lauret.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: It may, to be sure, be alledged—that Ger∣many was at first, in part, truly delineated by the Emi∣grants—and that afterwards, the revolution, which in the south caused so much calamity—has extended through the north, taste and cultivation.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: You are right, Viscount: a vulgar German girl, would laugh in your face—but I, who already feel the benign influence of your society, am so well bred as to make you a curtsey—and walk away.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! bravo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (calling after her) Whither Minna?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna
SP.P:
(turning to the stage) O! I am impatient to see Emma, and relate my adventures—the greatest de∣light
which a girl can bring home from a ball, is the prating about it for eight days after.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (exclaims, and touches his shoulder) What was that? a drop of rain!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: O! no: the sky is clear, and will not in∣terrupt our garden gala.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillach.
SP.P: But yet, do but see a wet spot upon my new frock.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Perhaps a dew drop, from the trees?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillach.
SP.P: Madam—you yesterday pronounced sen∣tence of death upon these cursed tall lindens.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My dear Emily, I implore mercy for these trees?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Are they interesting to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Inexpressibly so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I did not know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My poor sister and I planted them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (astonished) Thy sister! hast thou yet a sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I had one; but whether she survives, God knows?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: And thou never saidst a word to me about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Your pardon;—I dreaded the tearing open old wounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Neither did I it mentioned in thy family.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My Family, through false shame, avoids utter∣ing my poor sister's name. She loved, against her pa∣rents' approbation, a young merchant from Lyons—she yielded—and absconded—For two and twenty years she has been dead to us—most of my family have forgotten her—I will never forget her!

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Lyon! Lyon! I was born in that neigh∣bourhood. Ay, ay, the Lyonese are very seducing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
(caressing her husband) My dear hus∣band, I was on the point of doing a very foolish thing—but it was an omission on your part, not to have entrusted me sooner with so many important family occurrences—
from this moment, these linden trees are under my spe∣cial protection;—Viscount, I beg your frock's pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: But seriously—I must change my dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (smiling, and patting him on the shoul∣der) what could be more ageeeable to us women, than such noble occupation; my toilet also awaits me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: May I offer thee my arm?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Fie, Counsellor Flaxland; That were two Germanic—permit e, (presenting his arm).

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Viscount I have not yet been long e∣nough your pupil—the German wife every now and then twitches my gown. (She takes hold of her husband's arm.) A revoir Messieurs. (going) I shall soon rejoin you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX. The VISCOUNT, and HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Bravo! an original German joke.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I pity the French—if such actions constitute their jokes.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: What else?—matter for Florian's Nouvel∣les; or Arnaud's espreuves du sentiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You shrug your shoulders, Sir—I must tell you—your manners displease me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: We talk—we relate—we display our wit, but all in vain—there you sit—looking like the deaf and dumb, going, for the first time, to Abbe D'Epeés semi∣nary.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I had rather resemble the unlearned scholar, than the uninvited tutor.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: But this must not be, Sir: at your age, with your figure, one may dash at any thing—you have beautiful teeth, you should laugh—you have large eyes, you should ogle—you are well made, but you know not how to give your body those bewitching careless contours which captivate the sex; the undulating line is the line of beauty—a young man should always dis∣play his lineation—with his arms—his legs—his whole body.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (smiling) Unluckily I have been educated in the Cadet corps.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Yes, yes—that is evident—it will be an ar∣duous task to unbend you: en attendant, mon cher ami,—if you will entrust yourself to my tuition.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: You honor me.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: But under one condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I think I have observed you cast a presum∣ing eye upon Miss Flaxland—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Presuming—why yes—it is, to be sure, pre∣suming to love such an enchanting girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You love her then?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I am not ashamed loudly to acknowledge the noblest feeling of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: And for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I know not, Sir—by what title—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: What title?—parbleu—I will marry the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Why, so will I.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: She is —handsome—witty.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: She is good, sensible and amiable.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I will make her a Viscountess.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: And I, Mrs. Hugel.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: She cannot be both.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Probably, she may decline being either.

P.HI: Entre nous, mon cher ami, parlons raison.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Willingly, if it does not incommode you.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Minna must be my bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I would enter the lists for such a lovely prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: What, when I tell you—that I will not af∣terwards lay the least restraint upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: What means that?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Au contraire— you will oblige me in becom∣ing my wife's cecisbeo.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I have not learnt this in the Cadet corps.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Love—sigh—languish—as much as you please, I do not even require your patience for the ho∣ney-moon—l' ami de la maison will be ever welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Your most obliged.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: But till after the wedding, I must entreat you to keep your distance.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I am sorry—that my refractory heart—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: But Sir—I entreat!—do you understand me? the tone in which I entreat—will fully explain to you, what impression a refusal must make upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: The path of love is open, like the career of honor—we may march abreast—and he, who like you, Viscount, is conscious of his superior merit—what has he to fear?—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (disdainfully) To fear!—O! no—but this happens to be now my fancy—I will not endure any rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: But for this time you will permit—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: No—I permit nothing Sir—nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: That sounds somewhat dictatorial.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You compel me to speak plainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Miss Flaxland can best decide this contest.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I accept no lady for arbitrator, whilst I wear a sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I am not fond of knight-errantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Tant pis pour vous— for we must break a lance together.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I have long ground down my sabre into the peaceful sickle.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I would so much the more advise you to make your exit from a stage, where your part cannot be the most shining.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Competition does not always prove an unplea∣sant character.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You then persist in your obstinacy.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: When I peremptorily announce to you, that we must cut each other's throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You must shut out hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I consider all this exordium as a jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: There you are completely mistaken, Sir! Diable! I feel that your damn'd sang froid fevers my veins.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I entreat, Viscount!

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Superfluous—you leave the field—or draw the sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I shou'd be very reluctant.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (disdainfully) So I perceive; you have not probably ever seen blood shed in the Cadet corps.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: If you then positively command it.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You are still at liberty to decide.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: It is impossible for me to renounce Minna. (he coolly takes out his gloves and puts 'em on.)

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: I think it my duty as a nobleman, to cau∣tion you—that I was taught to fence by one of the most celebrated professors.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I thank you for this generosity—but 'tis too late. (he draws his sword.)

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Entre nous, mon ami—I emigrated—thro' the misfortune of having killed all the staff of my regi∣ment in duels.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Tant pis pour moi—I acknowledge the peril, and trouble. (he stands on his defence.)

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (drawg back, confused) How Sir?—what in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: How?—were you only in jest? (advancing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You do not recollect where we are.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: To be sure—it is not the proper place.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Even so:—not for the world!—I would never so far forget myself—to profane by a duel, a spot hallowed by hospitality!—upon the frontiers, Sir—upon the frontiers, will I run you through the body—and escape.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X. HUGEL, Solus.
DIV3.P:
And such a creature enjoys here free egress and re∣gress:—thus, many a coxcomb is endur'd, because he dances well—or because his hands are at command, if a lady wishes to wind off her thread—strange! that forward fools—and absurd fashions—should be thus indulged; but women will wear the one, and tolerate
the other—and they commonly ridicule both a month after—The saying—tell me thy company—and I will tell thee what thou art—cannot apply to the sex, for one finds lap-dogs and fools in favor, even with the most faultless female.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: Dancing and wind music heard at a distance.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. CAPTAIN ERLACH.

SP.P: Ho! ho!—It goes merrily here (looking towards the spot, whence the music is heard) hats—caps—feathers—dance and cards—whirling together—this suits me not! and this they call a summer pastime, when they transplant the card-table from the drawing room to the garden—a swarm of nats breaks up the party, and a drop of rain makes them scamper, as if it perforated through their skulls; there are those who slumber over the whole summer, and do not rouse themselves until the autumnal equinox—and my old friend tolerates such uproar in his garden?—my honest sedate Flaxland, how can this be explain'd?—who knows—may be his daughter's wedding?—if some domestic would but cross me—to whisper in his ear—Erlach is arrived.—I will not step too near this wild hurley-burley—I wou'd ra∣ther loiter in the ale-house—and muse over the hundred year calender—ho! there good friend!—why sure it is old John.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. CAPTAIN ERLACH and John.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Hey! hey!—by the I ord—his honor the lieu∣tenant—or rather, already, his honor the captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: 'Tis all one—if I am but welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: More welcome than an aloe in full bloom—a rare guest!—a dear guest!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I should be sorry to become here only a guest.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: How his honor will be rejoiced!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why, has one here leisure to enjoy an old friend?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: We have talk'd daily about you; when the linden tree blossom'd—or the melons ripened—it was ever—what a pity, my friend Erlach is not here?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Who was meanwhile dancing at the great harvest feast—where death swung the scythe.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Sometimes he complained, that you wrote so seldom.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Writing was never my passion.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: And that one never could exactly know where you were?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And what boots it?—the soldier is every where—and no where—like the old man in Spiessen's tales of ghosts. I have existed of late, like the wan∣dering Jew: But above all, I cannot endure, when friends are for ever scribbling each other their protesta∣tions of eternal friendship;—it must be self understood—for a friend is not like a girl, ador'd to day—neglect∣ed to-morrow;—apropos of girls—how fares it with my Emma? is she bravely grown?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Tall, good, and beautiful—a rose—a double rose!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I am glad of it;—here is company I per∣ceive.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Yes, to my sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou dost not like it old one?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Am not accustom'd to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And thy master? neither was it his custom.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ah me! here has been a great alteration.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Our new lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What? a new lady! it is not surely so?—a second wedding?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Not know that!—why 'tis going into the third year—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Indeed!—it is an unpleasant hearing—and he is deceived—it serves him right.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: A good lady—but too gay—too frolicksome—it seems to me like two kings in one hive—such hum∣ming, buzzing, and swarming.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Let the Counsellor know I am here—but se∣cretly—that it may not be mouthed about.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I understand you.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. ERLACH solus.
DIV3.P: Fares it then with marrying as with drinking—a de∣bauch creates head-ache, and scarcely sober, we again take the glass:—No, Erlach, thou hast done many a crazy thing in thy life-time—but thou wilt not marry—that is not thy doom:—He who stands on the beach, beholds the swimmers exhaust themselves—yet plunges into the flood—and deserves his fate.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. ERLACH and the COUNSELLOR.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (springs to him with open arms) Erlach! my Erlach! (the two friends press each other in silence to their hearts.)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (with sensibility) Old youngster! it joys me to see thee again: (he shakes him by the hand) I am truly glad!—thou art become rather thinner—but otherwise much the same:—why, I believe thou weep∣est—fie for shame: (he turns away to conceal his own tears) hem! a fly makes my eye water.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I weep!—yes:—and thank thee for not join∣ing the company, for there I must have suppressed these sweet tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So—but why hast thou such assemblies?—it displeases me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Of that hereafter;—let them dance and play—we have not met these eight years—dear Erlach, how fare you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I retire as Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Because it no longer pleased me—and because an old aunt had the sense to make me her heir.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I am glad of it—now we keep together.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Truly—that was my intention;—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Wherefore a but?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou hast ventured upon a second as I understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: An excellent woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: May be: yet this style of living— knowest me—it is not after my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Dost think it is agreeable to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why dost thou suffer what thou could'st prevent?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I am twenty years older than my wife—should I check her accustomed youthful amusements?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou should'st have taken that sooner into consideration.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I lov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: If thou preachest of love, I have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Has Erlach never acknowledged a mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Friend, it is with love, as with the small pox—who escapes it in youth, is seldom or ever in∣fected.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (smiling) But when caught it is the more dan∣gerous:—tho' to be serious—in thy present situation, what could'st thou do more sensibly than to marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What? why shoot myself—that were more rational.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What, ever the inveterate woman hater?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: If the woman is worthless, it is bad—and if good, it is still worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou art in jest?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Not in the least—I should love an amiabe woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: So much the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So much the worse:—a man who loves his wife, becomes the slave of his own heart—her desires, which he may not be able to gratify, torment him more than her.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: An amiable woman cherishes no such desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: But desires are like dust, that insinuates itself thro' bolts and locks.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: And by the breath of love is blown away.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Item—who takes unto himself a wife, must wean himself from an hundred little habits; which, since ten years, have become a second nature, and to which mankind generally adhere more obstinately, than either to their virtues or vices:—every one has his fa∣vorite dish—the chair he prefers sitting upon—his place at table, and so forth:—suddenly appears a fe∣male, as the household legislatix, and every thing must be moulde into another shape—the man wishes to dine on roast beef—but to please madam it must be fricas∣seed—the carriage is ordered, when he would rather be on horseback—and he abstains from tobacco, because she dislikes the smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (smiling) Trifles!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Sapling have their roots—which on all sides expand themselves in the soil—and at my years a man dislikes tearing up a flower, and even were it a weed.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: At thy years! why man—thou standest as yet with at least one foot in thy youthful lustre.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: But let us finally bring the dear creature to her sick bed—she has head-aches, I tremble—no ap∣petite, nor I neither—a fever, I am beside myself—and at length, a lying in—I am expiring thro' anxiety. No brother, this is not my calling.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But hast thou no conception of wedded bliss?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: O! yes:—thou lookest the picture of con∣nubial bliss!—and dost thou not include yonder tumul∣tuous revelry in thy catalogue of wedded joys?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (with a sigh) That might be otherwise, and peradventure may be otherwise!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Prithee say, where does the shoe pinch thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Ah! dear Erlach, more than one worm is gnawing at my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Speak the truth,—this manner of life:—thou lovest quiet—thou would'st rather retire to thy farm?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thro' love to my wife, I would roam from one carneval to the other; but the expence is too great—my purse cannot hold it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why dost thou not tell her so?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I cannot; under her parental roof, she was accustomed to this life; when a bride, she enquired with the most endearing confidence, the extent of my income:—I will most cheerfully accommodate myself—answer me sincerely?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And didst thou not do it?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I!—excuse me, my friend—I was ashamed!—live as heretofore, I replied, the means shall never fail you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And so it rested?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: She desired to know the conduct she should adopt! whether retirement was my object?—I shall conform entirely to your wishes, said she.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: But thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I could not bring myself to be, as it were, a kind of dictator, to constrain her: I studied to make her avoid recollecting, that she married a man turned of forty.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That implies—thou wast ashamed of thy age.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: May be.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And wouldst pass for a richer man, than thou art?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: It is now too late to retract.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Good sense, comes never too late—tho' she knocks at midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: That yet might pass—my heart disregards a diminished revenue—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yet, a but:—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: To thee, and to thee alone, I confess my weak∣ness—I am tortured by the demon of jealousy—daily, must I behold a swarm of admirers fluttering around her—they are to beure, mere foplings—but woe betide the man who imagines a fop cannot distress him—the necessity of amusement, ha often made female virtue fall the victim of amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why dost thou not tell her so?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: It is true, she has an hundred times enquired whether I also was jealous—one word, and I shall dis∣perse all these .

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And an hundred times, thou hast answered her—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Wh I heretofore answered her, as bride∣groom— my confidence in her, was boundless.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What is again, in other words, confessing, of thy jealousy.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Yes, Erlach.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: is not false shame a damnable weakness— would not be half so many miserables, could we had we but the resolution, to declare where the pain lies,—Here now stands a be happy—whose wife requires nothing more confidence—she wishes to be guided by him— whatever displeases him—but he—he is holds his tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I feel my error—but want the resolution to an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I must then occasionally lend thee some of my old bachelor frankness—be comforted! if thy wife re∣sembles thy description of her, there may be help for thee—that is my affair:—now tell me how fares my lit∣tle foundling? must I look for her in yonder circle?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou would'st seek her there in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I am glad of it—between ourselves brother, I have at heart the child's welfare—would she were but grown.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: O that she is already.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And that she were marriageable?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: O! that she is any day.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: You joke—she was a mere child, not taller than my rattan, when I was last here.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But in eight years it is easy to grow.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Surely—but the lass is yet blood young—destiny threw the poor orphan in my way, and I will faithfully provide for her—I have neither child nor fa∣mily—she shall call me pappa, as heretofore—and when old Nick makes me lead down death's dance, I shall leave my purse to her keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Hast thou discovered nothing of her origin?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Not a syllable:—but no matter—I can be as good a father to her as another.

SP.SPEAKER: Flex.
SP.P: Why not husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Art thou in thy ?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: She so heartily rejoiced at thy arrival—almost like a bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Ay, ay, did she so? then be quick—send her to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Instantly, (going) thou hast sent thy baggage to my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Not yet brother—thou knowest me—I must first find out, if all goes here as I like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My old friend—I cannot imagine—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Go, go, all that will find its own way.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V. ERLACH solus.
DIV3.P: We must first develope the lady's disposition—ma∣trimony has many a time administered an opiate to friendship—and once fallen asleep, she awakes never more: it is, as if love exhausted the spirit from the flask—leaving friendship only the vapour—from which evil, the Lord deliver us:—my poor Flaxland—and thou persuadest me to marry—thou! a decoy bird—sing as thou listest, we shun the net and the lime twig.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. ERLACH and EMMA.

SP.SPEAKER: Emm.
SP.P: (breathless and with outstretched arms) my deliverer! my benefactor!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (draws back and avoids her embrace, surpri∣zed) Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Have you forgotten your Emma?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (astonished) You! my Emma?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: And why not thou as formerly?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Can you be the identical Emma, who eight years since was not taller than my cane?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: And who could only then lisp, what she nw feels.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Who sat upon my knee, and was afraid of my beard?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: The same, whom you overwhelm with kind∣ness—and yet repel her grateful exultation.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (hesitating between doubt and affection) Well, well—if it be so, I am heartily glad—thou—you—hang ceremony—and run and kiss my dear girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: That, was the fatherly well-known voice.—(she embraces him)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (kisses her forehead, and contemplates her with admiration) Why, girl, thou art become tall and beautiful—thy eyes is tender—and all thy ways delight me—dost see?—I cannot tell how folks feel who have children—but at this moment, I would not give a doit for a living daughter (he touches her cheek) my heart is so light and joyful—do not laugh at me, for letting the water trickle down my cheek—this is not usual with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I laugh!—I am so overcome, (weeping)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou weepest!—dear Emma, I cannot stand this—I must go—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So, so, my lovely girl, with such a smile thou could'st halt a squadron on full charge—but now for a rational word—it cannot go on thus—thou and thee are no longer sitting.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Why not my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: But hang it, why your father?—do I then look so old? I am eight years younger than the Coun∣sellor.—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Your bounties—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What, again? (quick) Do you hear, dear Emma? (gentle) my good Emma—not a syllable more about it—it is not my way—and if it must be thee and thou, it may as well be as thy brother—at any rate a half brother, by a first marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: My heart does not require any relationship to love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So much the better—little comes of rela∣tions who only love one another for what little they can get.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You wrote us so seldom—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: My writing master rap'd my knuckles when I made crooked letters, and I have since been always averse to writing.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Your goodness!—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That is not the question—I could but spa∣ringly provide for thee—for I had nothing beyond my Reutenant's pay—but I shall go better in future:—we have inherited, my Emma, an old aunt, God bless her, has bequeathed us a pretty snug estate—I have therefore retired from the service, and purposed taking my winter quarters with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: O! that is delightful—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yes—but the style of living here, is not after my fashion—if it goes on at this rate every day—It is true—the Counsellor has told me that my Emma dislikes this bustle.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Custom has made solitude dear to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Custom only!—not then inclination—not impulse?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Do not therefore think the woe of a young girl—whose heart has sometimes throbb'd, when view∣ing at a distance the jocund crew.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlarch.
SP.P: Well? why didst thou not make one amongst them?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Because it did not become me—because I, a poor orphan—must subsist by others' liberality—be∣cause—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Because—well—fully out with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Before you—I will not conceal my weakness—because I could not flatter myself in splendid circles to supply through innate worth, the superiority of my companions in dazling finery.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: In plain words—that signifies—thou wast ashamed of thy wardrobe.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Not here—not in the society of superior be∣ings—but yonder—you know on what weak foundations—the world grounds its siokle judgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Another instance of false shame—dear Em∣ma—a maiden is richly drest—when adorned in the simple drapery of innocence—but thou must not want for any thing—now I like such an apron with pockets, it looks so domestic—but the pockets must not be empty. (he endeavours unobserved to put a purse in her pocket)

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (much ) No, no—in God's name, not so—you have misunderstood me—you humble me—I have more than I want—If you love me take back the oney.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Be but quiet (he replaces the money) I have not managed this cleverly—pardon me—I am too down∣right—the art of giving is a fine art—and unfortunate∣ly, I do not understand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: What I meant to confess as a the appearance of effrontery—I am rather as a daughter, or a sister—ow they to force upon trinkets —I may still perhaps —whilst I am revelling a common peasant girl— my ears?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: A —no indeed, no!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: () Know you perchance

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: dear child—only vague surmises.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Of relate to me these surmises—the tale of my deliverance; when you quitted us eight years since, I was a child, and could not understand it—it is true; that the counseller has often related to me what he learnt from you—but the little local incidents—which can only interest me—escaped his attention—and how often a trifle is a clue to the most important discovers!—I will assist you with my faint infantine recollections—I will describe to you my mother's figure—perhaps she yet survives!—gracious God—she may still be alive!—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P:
Possibly!—but not probably!—we made good our landing in the night—surprzied Charleston—our people were disguis'd by liquor—they became in∣cendiaries—the town flam'd at every corner—and those who spring from the fire, fell by the bayone!—no com∣mander—no subordination—I think with horror on that infernal night—I had shouted myself hoarse—tho' thunder would have roll'd unheard—At length the day dawned—and enlightened the murd'rous scene—cover∣ed
with dust and blood—blackened by smoke and ashes—our men laid snoaring around—all was horror—and in that stillness of desolation, I scrambled sword in hand over the smoaking ruins—when suddenly I heard a faint murmuring under my feet—I listened—I re∣moved away the glowing fragments—when an infant countenance looked piteously at me—and cried mother! mother! it was thou, dearest Emma!—thy body laid half buried in soot—a miracle had preserv'd thy exist∣ence—I loosen'd the soot—one of thy little hands got free—and thy first use of it was to waft me a kiss—this inexpressibly affected me—Patience, poor worm, said I—thou mayest yet be eleved—my groom was near—and together we rais'd thee unhurt into the face of day—I took thee in my arms—and thou clung around my neck—To my mother!—saidst thou in English—to my mother!—thou repeatedst in French—and at last in German—because thou thoughtest I did not understand thee.—Who is thy mother? I enquir'd—here in the nar∣row street—the good woman—at the yellow house.—But there were no more—neither narrow or broad streets, neither woman or house—I exerted every effort to make some discovery—the few who had saved themselves had crawled into the woods—we re-embark'd—What was to be done?—could I abandon thee among the burning ru∣ins?—My captain permitted my taking thee with me—he was mov'd when he beheld thee—for thou wast so little—so little—that I cannot even now comprehend—how thou couldest grow thus tall.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Alas!—and do you not know more?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (shruge his shoulders) We made a safe voy∣age to Europe—and thou foundest an asylum in my friend's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Could I not once lisp out to you my name?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thy christian name, Emma—which makes me British—but thy French and German were equally correct—thou art therefore of no vulgar origin—thy was mark'd A. M. and this is all I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: O! would I were once there!—could I but view my parents?—I should certainly recognize them—my father was a dark thin man—and my mother!—her form I never can forget—she look'd so pale—and wept so frequently—and now, perhaps, she weeps oftener than ever—and I dare not mingle my tears with her's.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Compose thyself dear Emma—I see the holi∣day squadron prancing down the alley—such tears are too precious for creatures who have whirl'd away their bit of feeling in the dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I cannot just now recover myself, but suffer me to go? (she retires)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (alone) Excellent girl!—only a pity, that she has grown so tall and handsome: the heart cannot be so unreserved as formerly, and—thou—faints on the tongue—I will, however, remove my trunk hither.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII. ERLACH, MRS. FLAXLAND, MINNA, HUGEL and EMMA.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Welcome Captain; heartily welcome! I just now understand from my husband—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (with cool politeness) Have I the honor to be in Mrs. Flaxland's presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: If it does not give you more satisfaction than honor—I must count another wish ungratified.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Bravo! that is fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Your wishes are very temperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: We have been expecting you for an eternity.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So much the worse for me—for the expected seldom answer the expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I have an hundred times had your man∣ner and appearance repeated to me—for when I hear of interesting persons—I love to sketch an outline—which at last seldom resembles the original: for example—I have always figur'd you to be a lively, jovial man—with the nose of an eagle, and the eye of a falcon.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I would have wager'd Wieland's Musa∣ion, your eyes were not of such a dark hazel.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—bravo!—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: A cheerful spirit sometimes posts stern cen∣tinels—to check merauders—(fixing his eye on Maillac)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: But Captain—if friendship undertakes to seize a heart by surprize—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Friendship only surprizes fools.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: You are right—I should have said by conquest—she then eludes mistrust, who guards the out∣post—in short, I am resolved to be your friend—that I may no longer continue your rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Rival!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Yes Sir, yes: more than once have I been heartily jealous of you—not a day passes but my husband expatiates upon you with enthusiam;—It is a passion—a longing!—were I suspicious—I shou'd have fear'd to behold in ou, a second Chevalier d'Eon.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! bravissimo.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Viscount, I excuse you from the duty of applauding each of my words

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! bravo, bravissimo.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (to Minna) Little censor, thou shalt repay me this.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: What, will you make more verses upon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: It nearly comes to my turn to cry bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Minna. (to Erlach)
SP.P: Will you again restore the word to honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (smiling) Indeed! my beautiful unknown!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: How! do you not know your friend's daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (surprised) What! can that be the Minchen? your pardon, Mademoisselle Wilhelmina!

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: O! keep ever by Minna—otherwise, for the first time, I shall grieve at being grown tall.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, you are grown tall and hand∣some.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And can also blush brave captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Flattery is not my way—beauty is like nobi∣lity—it does not make the wise vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillach.
SP.P: Ah! Captain, she is as cruel as she is beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (to Minna) An admirer I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Yes, a bit of one—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Monsieur le Vicote de Maillace—a French emigrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So, so—your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: And here is Herr von Hugel, a worthy country gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That is my object—to this gentleman I am already nearly related—for we Swiss are naturalized to a country life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Your arm Captain, to join the company, where you shall hear a medley of names and titles an∣nounced.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I had rather be introduced to a bed of hy∣acinths—for when I understood this to be a premier noble—and that a Cardinal de Fleury—I should at least be rewarded by the smell.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Monsieur le Capitaine, seems to be infected with the new philosophie?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Infected!—Bravo! the expression is select—we shall soon begin to build quarantine houses on the frontiers—to stop travellers, posting in the country, infected with the plague of reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: You bear yourself a name of renown.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Unfortunately: it has often tormented me: if perchance presented at court, it was buz'd thro' the circle—are you descended from the famous Rudolph Erlach? my God, yes—but am I a hair the better, or the taller for it? I Hans Erlach, serve God and my king to the best of my ability—whoever likes me on that score, let us shake hands as friends: but let no man touch his bonnet to me on account of Rudolph Erlach, whose bones moulder under Strasburg Cathedral.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Well, my gallant Captain, I give you my hand, as the friend of Hans Erlach—but you must not forget, that when with wolves, we must join in the howl.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Your pardon:—that is one of the senseless bye-words—we should never howl with wolves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: But all this while my poor husband is confined among them: let us hasten to release him! (she drags him away with her)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (following her reluctantly) I am your prison∣er—and assuredly prisoners may be made to serve as pioneers.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII. MINNA, the VISCOUNT, Herr von HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Le Capitaine—is rather massif.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: No summer-house—such buildings shelter friendship in winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Shall we follow, to the company?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: You joke—the comet never asks his tail, whether it will follow!

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—do you know that the tails of comets are said to be composed from an exhalation of vapours?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Compos'd as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Are you of that opinion Herr von Hugel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I can find no comparison to Minna equal to herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (throws herself upon the bank) Well then gentlemen—we will remain here—I am in no talking vein—I must be amused, and care not how.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Could I avail myself of this heure de Berger, and discourse of my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: No, no:—do you not hear? I will be amused!

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Perhaps you may like reading? I have here a volume of Rousseau's Nouvelle Heloise.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: A book I dare not read—papa does not per∣mit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I have Woldemar's Jacobis in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Emma and I have read that twice through—but tell me Viscount, why is your book stiled la Nou∣velle Heloise?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Probably the author's caprice—for I cannot discover thro' the whole work, one syllable about an Heloise.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: It must however bear some reference.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Most assuredly.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Heloisa must have been extremely beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: (presenting Minna his snuff-box) I can have the honor to shew you her portrait.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Does it resemble her?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Like two dew drops.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (cunningly) Perhaps you were acquainted?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Not with her—she has been dead some years—but I knew her uncle Fulbert—an honest old fellow—there is a copper plate of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: You smile, Herr von Hugel.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I participate in your amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: We were conversing about the uncle, Vis∣count—I suppose a person of some consequence?—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: A financier—one does not investigate these gentry so precisely—they keep an excellent table.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And Abelard?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: Was at that time. avocat au parlement, and had acquir'd some reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Likewise I presume an elderly man?

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: In the prime of life—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (smiling) O, yes!—he can scarcely be more than six or seven hundred years old—

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: How, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: At least, Bayle asserts, he was born in the eleventh century.

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: That is false—I must know better than the obscure person you mention.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Bayle! an obscure person!

SP.SPEAKER: Maillac.
SP.P: In short, Sir, he, who can to his face accuse a man of my condition of an untruth.—He, at least be∣trays—that he is no Frenchman.—This Abelard is a man between forty and fifty, which I assert upon my honor!—understand me, upon my honor; and there the affair is decided.—Should you, notwithstanding this op∣position, remain in doubt, I am prepared to give you, in the adjoining field, the most unequivocal proofs—(He bows to Minna, casts a haughty look at Hugel, and

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX. MINNA and HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Why, this is a challenge in due form.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: So it appears.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And you do not go?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Because I already know thro' experience—that on foot there is no overtaking him.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: It would be comical for you to fight about Abelard.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Men have often cut one another's throats, for objects equally insignificant.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And have been chronicled as martyrs.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Presumption is also a passion—and our passi∣ons are frequently but a stimulus, to be roused by oppo∣sition.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: This should not be acknowledged to us girls.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Because it might make our sex mistrust the love of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Did I then mention love?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Is not love also a passion?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Not true love—which enables our existence, and becomes the innate impulse to all that is good and great.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I doubt—whether this definition would suit the taste of my sex?—We are but too fond to excite passions—and to make philosophy ridiculous, reason, crown'd with fool's cap, kneeling at the feet of beauty—an engaging picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: But only in water colours—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Girls are seldom judges.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Nor will they be judges—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Detraction, my good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I wish you were open to demonstration.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: We have demonstration at heart, but men in our heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Heart and head, should promote a friendly in∣tercourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: O! Such an intercourse were too tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Or marry!—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Wedlock would be yet more tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: You are not serious—but I am confident that at your golden wedding, you will defend holy matrimo∣ny, with all the animation of youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: At my golden wedding! heaven forbid!—to survive that, I must at latest marry to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Which must wholly depend upon yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Upon me?—comical enough!—as if it de∣pended on one's self to resolve, to day I will give away my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Why not?—as easy as to declare, to-day my ear shall not be shut against the poor beggar—to-day, I will comfort the unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: My sagacious Sir—you over-rate the worth of a maiden's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I only alluded to your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Which I conjecture—you cannot compre∣hend.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I! not comprehend your heart?—then must the sweet remembrance of my childhood be obliterated!—whither are flown those happy times—when your fa∣ther resided on his estate—and lived in friendly inter∣course with mine—when each fine summer evening, as∣sembled us children in the village—you beckon'd me kindly from afar—and called me, thou, and Augustus!—when suddenly, the frolicksome Minna vanish'd from our sports—to share her penny with a beggar—or to as∣sist a fallen child—When she industriously gather'd the strawberries for her father—or selected flowers to cele∣brate her mother's birth-day.—O! Minna! Minna—I—not know your heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (distrait) Those were happy hours!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Blest with innocence and peace of mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Nothing can be compar'd with the enchant∣ment of our early youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Except it be the charm of first love.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: The one as transitory as the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P:
A random observation from the great world.—in cities every thing is painted—landscapes upon can∣vas—health upon the cheeks—and love upon the stage—in cities, words are appreciated by fashion—in the country, they flow from feeling—in cities they say, your obedient servant—in the country, good day:—the first is politeness—the second heartiness:—I love you, exclaims
the townsman, with a I love thee, says the countryman, with a glistning the first repeats the word an hundred times a day— other expresses it but once in his life—To the one love is a mere pastime—to the other the enjoyment of life—here a gawdy flower, the shew of a summer's day—and there a shel∣tering foliage from rain, and the parching sun—an in∣strument never out of tune, thro' change of weather.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I now hear for the first time, that you are also a poet.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (drooping) O! my throbbing heart!—thy sensibility is misconstrued into fiction.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I begin to fear thee—romance is infectious.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Romance—I have been but too much inur'd to hear the genuine taste for love and nature thus abus'd—I therefore rivetted my heart—and threw not the key into the ocean of the world—but treasur'd it, as unfold∣ing the ideas of my hopes and wishes—I wish'd to dis∣cover the female, to whom the unpresuming youth was more deserving than the pert coxcomb—who, at a gala ball—would not pass with a contemptuous leer, the rus∣tic noble—because unpractised in the dance—and who, at the sumptuous board, did not mistake silence for dull∣ness:—Ah! I thought to have found her—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (in a soft hesitating tone) And were mis∣taken!—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P:
(with enthusiasm) No, no—I am not mista∣ken!—This tender inquietude manifests your beautiful soul—yes, I often rejoic'd to behold, amidst the bustle of the world, your lovely countenance, clouded with listlessness and ennui—that where your heart was not in∣terested, you could display your judgment.—O! fly these baneful circles, which oppose bulwarks against reason—card-houses against licentiousness—where those style themselves friends, who dissipate one another's time; where one is familiariz'd to love—by calculating that together the revenues suffice to fit up a house—where the possessor is reputed generous, if, on a Sunday afternoon, he distributes twelve-pence among a dozen
poor—and he is esteemed pious, thro' forbearance to talk of his religion, from the fear of being bewildered and misled—where the honest fellow inwardly despises the powerful scoundrel, to whom he is compelled to pay obeisance—where we compassionate the distress'd whilst shuffling the cards—and by the third trick have utterly forgotten them:—in short, where egotism mingles with interest—fear produces meanness—and the habitude of vice masks its deformity. Fly from this pestiferous atmosphere to rural scenes, where every noble feeling is excited—there is the heart unfolded to the good and beautiful—there, love and friendship are not visitors, but residents—God is honor'd, when with wondering transport we view the starry heaven—We give to the poor to relieve their wants—vanity mingles not her ostentatious gifts, among the precious contributions of benevolence—there is mirth without cards, and con∣versation without detraction—one is not ashamed to esteem oppressed worth, and loudly to proclaim, a scroundrel—a scroundrel. O! I possess only a slender patrimony—but, if to all the blessings which industry, fortune, and my heart bestow upon me, Minna designs to contribute love—my little paradise will only want a ridge of lofty rocks, to make it impenetrable to envy.—You are silent.—The lively Minna casts down her eyes, and contemplates the flowers in her bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Methinks Herr von Hugel, it is a proof of my esteem for you—that, at this instant, my levity for∣sakes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: your esteem is my pride, but only love gives bliss.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Ere I answer you, confess to me sincerely.—what proportion does my figure hold in your love?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Sincerely, my best Minna—I have never examin'd myself, as to that point.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Then do it now—it materially interests me to know it:—Should I, think you, have engag'd your affections, had I been ugly and deform'd?—I appeal to your honor and honesty, for a faithful answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P:
Well then, why should I disavow an impres∣sion, which youth and beauty produce in every well
organiz'd frame:—I shou'd love you, even were you plain—but whether I should have so clearly recogniz'd your soul, concealed in such unseemliness, I cannot venture to pronounce.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: And supposing the small-pox should suddenly disfigure me, or if I be not what I seem?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: What a supposition?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Girls are skilful in concealing their imper∣fections.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: My life upon the venture.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: You shall venture nothing—she, who will de∣ceive an honest man, cannot deserve his love—(she takes his hand) I—Herr von Hugel, highly esteem you—something more perhaps—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: No but.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I must confess to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (trembling) That your heart is engaged?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: My heart is free.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Well?—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: I am—I appear—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: O! you are what you appear—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: No! no! I—
SP.STAGE: (The musicians at a distance play a Waltz.)

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (uneasy and confused) Dancing is renew∣ed—shall we join the company?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Without indulging me with an answer?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I will answer you soon, though not now:—this waltz—it delights me—come, come along, and let us dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: It is out of my power at present to dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Indeed!—the music is so inviting—you will not then?—excuse me Herr von Hugel, I must look out for a partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P:
(looks after her amaz'd) Is it possible?—God! is this possible?—the acknowledgment of heart—felt passion dissipated by a wretched waltz—she disco∣vered an honest man, but she sought a dancer.—Now then farewell, the holy belief in innocence and nature
—away Hugel, and hide thyself under thy thatch—water thy salads—and scare the birds from thy domain, that their notes may not remind thee of this cursed waltz.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. CAPTAIN ERLACH
DIV3.P:
ABUNDANCE of eating and drinking—a peal of laughter—but no pure enjoyment:—he who laughs with all his might, is not of course always happy—one laughs at his own wit, and if he be rich, or powerful, the circle is constrained to join in chorus—another laughs at a double entendre, of his own painful invention, and ogles the ladies around to enjoy their confusion—here titters a gosling, to disguise an auk ward timidity—and there leers an ape, because his neighbour's tail is a hair too long:—here is a good soul of a mother relating her offspring's display of genius, and compelling her yawning hearers to join in the admiration—yonder, is a sketch discussing, from the magazine of scandal, and a malignant smile blasts the opening bud—when they re∣turn home, says his Excellency to her Excellency, what a delicious party—how heartily we have laugh'd:—No; this is not after my way—the most rational among the groupe, seems to be the Counsellor's lady—a canary bird among bullfinches—warbling to them, till they imitate a tune or two—if sometimes her wild notes escape her, they are lovely melodious tones;—could she but know how her husband is chagrined—but patience—she shall learn it. Once domesticated together a couple of months under one roof— couple of months!—why Erlach, can'st thou swim so long in this strunge ele∣ment?—why not?—Flaxland is my friend—and Emma!—what choaks thee old boy?—daughter—sisiter—friend
—no matter how I call her, I dearly love her, and ha∣ving once for all saved her from perishing—why—ay—so—a good girl—only one thing in her displeases me—the should not, mean while, have grown eight years older.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. EMMA and ERLACH.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (looking about for some one and perceives Er∣lach) Ah! you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I am here, my dear child—were you looking for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: No:—I was seeking—I want to speak with some one, who has crept into some bush, God knows where. (she gives him a friendly nod)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (solus) Most obedient!—that was not me∣thinks so pretty in her!—she might as well have remain∣ed a couple of minutes, and chatted a word or two about the weather: hem!—whom can she be seeking?—who is this some one? and what can she have so urgent to say to him?—Some one!—why that may be a female—tho' I will wager it is a man!—O! ho, Miss Emma—perhaps a secret of the heart:—well! what is that to me?—am I not her—her father?—she dared not amuse me about the blank nobody: I, however, surely deserved a particle of confidence, just for a word at parting—to have been whispered this somebody is nam'd so and so—but so it is, when girls become eight years older.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. ERLACH and MRS. FLAXLAND.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: My dear captain, you court solitude!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: It is difficult to meet her in these quarters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Is that praise, or blame?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I never dispute upon taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I understand:—but do not misconstrue into taste, what with me is only custom—and not seldom a tiresome custom.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What hinders you from shaking off this tire∣some custom?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: My husband likes this manner of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He like this life?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
If we are alone, he instantly becomes un∣easy—inquires twenty times in an hour, if I am not
va∣pour'd—if I will not make such and such a visit—and is not easy till I order the carriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And accompanies you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Seldom! only when I earnestly entreat him.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What can he do at home alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (playful) God knows:—peradventure, he makes gold—at least, when I return, he always re∣ceives me as cordially, and as kindly, as if he had dis∣covered a treasure,

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Ha! this grieves me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: How!—what grieves you?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
