SP.P: To hear that my honest friend, since our se∣paration, has learnt to disguise himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Disguise! how so?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: No such alteration occurs to a man at his years.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Speak more intelligibly.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I had rather be silent—we do not as yet know enough of one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Not know one another! when my hus∣band gave me a right to his affection, he gave me also a right to vour friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Friendship and old hock are good—but mixt with a sharpness, not perhaps to every one's taste.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax:
SP.P: You excite my curiosity more and more:—I beeech you Captain, don't count me among the formal beings who screw up their mouths at a truism, because it is somewhat bitter;—our acquaintance is yet young—but were I slumbering on a bed of roses, and a stranger preserved me from a viper's sting, this stranger would become my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: If you think thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
Indeed, I think thus:—to please my husband is my most earnest wish—to be sure the differ∣ence in our ages is considerable, and I did not fall into his arms thro' love, but was some how surpriz'd into them thro' esteem:—we have not acted a romance to∣gether—no light'ning has inflamed, but a chearing marriage sun has constantly animated us: be you then animated to speak confidently—but, notwithstanding
this declaration, should my presence any way confuse you—I will place myself behind these trees—forget my being here, and you need not spare me in a soli∣loquy.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Bravo!—that is my way, those who think thus, I esteem highly—and to those I esteem highly, I speak the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Forward then—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: How can a woman with such an excellent head and heart, endure so many fools about her:

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Alas! dear Captain—should we banish fools—our circles would become very circumscrib'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The smaller the better—sense and sociability are guests who disappear if they behold lights at every window.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: But folly lends good sense a foil.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: She does not want it—and if your husband has pretended to like this manner of life, he has de∣ceived you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Flax.
SP.P: That would grieve me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He thought this indulgence was due to your youth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Then he little knew me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He feared you might imagine—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That he was jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Jealous!—you joke!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Should I for example assure you, that last night he never closed an eye—that his imagination kept him on the rack till morning—that he was oblig'd to force himself away, when he heard your carriage draw up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I am all astonishment!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: It gnaws my heart-strings, sigh'd he mourn∣fully—I endeavor in vain to conquer this weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: My God!—why did he not say so to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: False shame—the demon of confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
Well, I have hitherto left our company to a chance medley—in future, he shall have the se∣lection—he shall be my constant companion—this very
day he shall make out a list, and name the persons whose acquaintance he esteems.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The list will be very short!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Not so:—there are here many worthy, sensible characters.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: O! yes—but the more there are—so much the more difficult for an individual, who is no to treat them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: What do you mean?—Flaxland is rich!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He was!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He may yet be called in good circumstan∣ces—but if his property continues to be melted, as it has been for these last three years—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: My good Sir, you alarm me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Where the outgoings so far exceeded the in∣come—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Can it be possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He might, peradventure, 'ere long have been compelled to infringe upon the maternal patrimony of his children.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: My God!—why did he not tell me this?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: False shame!—the less riches the less esteem.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: But not in my eyes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: He has long wished to retire to is farm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Willingly:—heartily;—this present e∣vening.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: But he fears at your age, that country same∣nes—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
O! how it distresses me—that my hus∣band did not think it worth while to appreciate my cha∣racter—that a stranger should repose more confidence in me, than a man of whose affection I am proud—that I should injure his children, and destroy his peace of mind!—that I should dissipate the savings of pater∣nal solicitude and maternal affection!—why did he no put me to the proof? why did he suppose that a swarm of coxcombs could entertain me better than domestic quiet, and the converse of a well inform'd man! O! Captain Erlach, men so often reproach us for our weak∣ness
—it is no weakness—it is the soul's softness—and it chiefly depends upon you to mould it into goodness—but you conceive that female love ill accords with truth—you require health and soundness of soul, and yet poison it with flattery:—but I am complaining and arguing, where I should be acting—your hand, dear Captain, you shall witness and acknowledge that I merit your confi∣dence.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (alone) Why right! this is my way—if she keeps her word—I remain here:—but if I stay, the lass must alter her manner, and not run away from me—she must have confidence in me—I should like, however, to learn if she has found her plaguy somebody.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. ERLACH and HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Here comes one who has disentangled him∣self from the Babel, and tries to compose his ears:—welcome Herr von Hugel—I wish you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (starting) Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Of solitude. Some good folks imitate the nightingales—when surrounded by clamor they are silent—you did not seem yonder to be in your right place.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I at least resemble the nightingales, by feel∣ing myself in my proper place only in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: You are complimenting yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Were my attachment to a country life, a pri∣vilege, I should share this privilege with every clown.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Would he thereby lose ought of his worth?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Yes; with many.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: If you allude to the French locusts, who here infect the air—you may be right.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: No, no:—better men—perhaps the —yonder Frenchman for example—I dare not to appreciate him—but he pleases—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: He is prepossessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (sighing) He is probably beloved.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (more uneasy than inquisitive) By whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Ah! by a lady, who fails in nothing, but the faculty to discern the heart which reflects her image.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And this lady! for as to the heart, I know it!—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: You know it!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yes, without the faculty of looking into it—but the lady?—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: That, methinks, you might easily have di∣vined—for I said expressly—that nothing fail'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Most obedient—(aside) he certainly spoke of Emma. (loud) You believe then, she is partial to the Frenchman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I must also fear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (half to himself) Hem!—should he be the some one, she so anxiously sought!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (eager) How!—she sought?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: A somebody—the devil take him—with such haste, she was near tumbling over me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: She was panting to speak with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I lament the search was fruitless—as an hour before, he walk'd away with a couple of courtiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (murmuring to himself) Accursed coxcomb—such a girl, without a failing—only too old—too old—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: How too old?—she is only sixteen.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So much the worse.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE V. EMMA enters, and exclaims on perceiving HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (surprized) I, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (amazed) Hem—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I have been looking for you above an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I was wandering in the meadow, not sup∣posing that here, I could be miss'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So he was the some one whom you sought?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Yes, dear Captain—I have something of im∣portance, to communicate to Herr von Hugel.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Probably also a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Emma has no secret for her benefactor—but it concerns a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (feelingly) So, so—I comprehend—constrain, is not my way—I shall soon enough learn the secret from the bridegroom.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. EMMA and HUGEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Herr von Hugel, I have a msssage to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: If this message gives me pain, which I greatly apprehend, there has been at least the consideration to choose an asswaging messenger.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I hope to be messenger of peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Peace precludes discord—and I knew not—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You have told my friend you lov'd her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Only told—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: No sophistry,—by your leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Well then—to my sorrow, I love Minna!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Why to your sorrow?—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I am a plain countryman—which for a mo∣ment, I ceas'd to recollect—Minna has deeply hum∣bled me—it will never again be forgotten.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Humbled!—that is a hard expression.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: The occasion was harder than the expression—she, who treats a serious proposal, as a jest—she, whose levity hurries a man with the tears of love in his eyes to a dance—let me say, does not that imply contempt?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dear Herr von Hugel—beware of an intem∣perate judgment—you may repent at Minna's feet:—Do you make no allowance for a poor girl's embarrass∣ment?—I assure you, that most of the follies of which we are accused towards your sex—arise from embarass∣ment—how, if Minna was heartily well disposed to you?—but only shy of a certain confession, which she fear∣ed, might in the eyes of the lover, diminish the worth of the beloved.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (smiling sarcastically) You are supposing a case?—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P:
I suppose nothing—there are certain points, Herr von Hugel, which to our sex are very important,
but which, fortunately, do not always strike your eyes: should a girl be not completely what she seems to be, she may, if she can, deceive the public, but not the man whom she intends to marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Minna is not what she seems?—I do not un∣derstand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Minna is very beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: O! certainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: A charming shape.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Why, tell me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You find her faultless!

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: You are in jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: A man, and especially a lover, cannot be an accurate observer—we females examine more closely.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: I beseech you to speak plainer.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Know then, that Minna's apparent levity arose from being ashamed to acknowledge to you, what she thought indispensable—that she—strange!—I am almost myself ashamed—(in haste) that she is some∣what mis-shaped—at last—it is out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Mis-shaped!—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: On the left side—she fell down stairs from her nurse's arms—dress can conceal the defect—but to the eyes of her future husband, she wish'd not to appear more engaging than she really is—now you have a key to the enigma. False shame deterr'd her from telling you herself—for most females would rather avoid a men∣tal defect, than a corporeal failing:—Minna does not belong to this common class—her tongue only denied its service. Now you know all—you know what she has lost in the attraction of her form—and what she acquired in the beauty of her soul:—my friend murmured softly in my ear, Emma, I love him!—but that let him rather hope than know—You see, I have exceeded my powers—the coming moment will evince, whether I must re∣pent my precipitancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (transported) Is this a dream?—Minna!—noblest Minna!—where is she?—where can I find her?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dare I inquire with what intention?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: And can you inquire?—my beloved!—my bride!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: It is as I expected—go—where she is I know not—intinct guides a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (hastens away) Minna!—Minna!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VII. EMMA alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Go then—but thou wlt not soon find her—probably she has crept, thro' false shame, into some nook or other—there she sits forlorn, and listens—and her heart often throbs high at the idea—Emma is now speaking to him—(she sighs) How is this?—I catch myself at a sigh!—my bosom is not surely nurturing envy at my friend's happiness!—No, no—but a maiden may be allowed to confess, that to find a deserving, ac∣complished husband, is truly enviable—Erlah seemed to go away murmuring and uneasy—he did not relish leaving me alone with Hugel—why so?—girl! girl! do not disclose to any one, what thou now thinkest. (she retires slowly in a reverie)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII. MADAME MOREAU appears, very meanly, though cleanly dressed; she supports herself on a walking cane, sometimes stopping, and looking mournfully around; at length she approaches EMMA, unobserved, and contemplates her from head to foot, with mingled emotion and curiosity.

SP.SPEAKER: Madame Moreau.
SP.P: Your pardon, Mademoiselle.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (starting from her reverie) Who are you, Madam?—whom may you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Is this counsellor Flaxland's house?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: You are perhaps his daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Would I could answer yes to that question—do you wish to speak to the counsellor?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Extremely—if convenient.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Follow me—I will conduct you to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Is he alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I believe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: If he be quite disengaged, I wish he would condescend, thro' compassion to an aged woman, who cannot well ascend the steps, to meet me in the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I will tell him so.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Has he any family?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: One son in the army, and a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: And you are not this daughter?—that's a pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You are very kind, Madam—whom shall I announce to the counsellor?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: A poor old woman—nothing else:—I hope to be in a mansion, where this title will neither shut door nor heart against me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I find you well know the counsellor—he will be instantly here.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX. MADAME MOREAU, alone.

SP.P: Indeed! ah! good child! confidence in mankind is a tender plant, so seldom cherished by the milk of human kindness, that at length it perishes; yes—formerly he was benevolent and compassionate, but also young! youth is tender, but age indurates all; and what dare I hope from a brother, when my only son—hush, hush; speak it not aloud—poor mother! rather think it was a dream, and be silent—will he not be asham'd of me? The rich have cousins and aunts in every corner of the world; poverty is only related to misery: it were better to conceal who I am, and first notice his manner and reception: Perhaps, I may be more welcome as an ob∣ject of benevolence, than if I demanded his assistance as an act of duty! Methinks,—yes,—O God! how my heart beats! do not betray thyself! For if thou must again abandon this house, where wilt thou find a grave

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X. Counsellor FLAXLAND and Madame MOREAU.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My foster daughter tells me, you wish to spea with me—how can I serve you?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: I am an Emigrant—had house and home husband and children—and am now reduced to this staff but had rather starve, than stoop to beggary—in my youth, I learnt much for my amusement, but which now, perhaps, in my old age, might procure me my bread—I can sew and wash, cook and bake:—most worthy Sir, do you want an housekeeper?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I must, with regret, Madam, say no.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: You have probably some young children, whom I might instruct in English and French?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I have only a daughter, who is grown up.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Oh God!—must I then also leave this man∣sion without consolation?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No, Madam—that shall not be; I have friends to whom I will recommend you—and mean while you may occupy a spare room, and a vacant place at my table.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: God reward you with an ever cheerful heart!—My friend spoke truth, when she promised me here a welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Your friend! You have perhaps a recommen∣dation to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau
SP.P: I was born at Lyons, and knew there, seve∣ral years since, an unfortunate German lady, Philipine Moreau.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: God! my sister! does she yet live?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: She is dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Dead! (tears burst from his eyes; he turns, and leans against a tree, weeping)

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (aside, with uplifted hands) He yet loves me—there is yet some one in the world who loves me!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (looking aghast) The first intelligence in twen∣ty years! she is dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: She died in misery!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Oh! why was she so forgetful of her only bro∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: She did not forget him, but was silent thro' shame. Can I, said she, intrude myself upon my bro∣ther in rags? will he not reproach me with my weak∣ness?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: How could she thus misconstrue her William's heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Shall I revisit my paternal roof, to learn that my good parents bequeathed me their curse as an inheritance?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Both father and mother blest her on their death bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Blest her! O! that I could convey this word of comfort into my friend's grave!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Long, long, have I hoped that she would at length recollect the brother, whom, when a lad, she so heartily loved.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (animated) Yes, yes, that did she! (composes herself) she has often assured me of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My hopes of seeing her again grew with these trees—I planted the one, and my sister the other—time has interwoven their branches, but has torn my sister's heart from mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (greatly affected) No, no!—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Our dear mother planted yonder arbour, a year before her death—I shall not live, said she, to behold these tender shoots extend their shade, but perhaps thou and thy sister may one day sit under them and remem∣ber me.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (endeavoring in vain to repress her tears) I can no longer!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (embracing one of the linden trees) I envy our forefathers their delightful superstition—how fondly could I believe my sister's spirit in this tree.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (sinks down on her staff) My brother William!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (hastening to her) God! what is this!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (kneeling, her arms cutspread) William! my brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (precipitating himself into her arms) Phillip∣pine art thou her?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: I am:—do not spurn me!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I spurn thee—(a pause)

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: My good William, lead me under the lin∣den trees, which we planted on our mother's birth day—we then embraced each other, and our parent smiled with fraternal love—let me once more, under their shade press thee to my heart, and the mother will again look down and smile.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P:
(conducts his sister to the trees; awbraces her tenderly; looks up with tearful eyes, and exclaims)
Mother rejoice with us!—the Almighty has granted thee for us this hallowed moment!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (leans her head on his breast) Here let me die!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Here shalt thou by my side retrace our youth∣ful endearments—leaning on my arm revisit every tree, whence we used to gather fruit, and yonder daisy bank, where we often reposed—then will I lead thee to the paternal roof, and shew the chamber which was called thine—the nut-brown table yet remains where we learnt to draw, and the closet where thou treasur'd me up bon bons (he casts his eye on Madame Moreau, who is faint∣ing on his breast) thou hearest me not! sister, how art thou? this deadly paleness!—in God's name, help! help!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XI. EMMA and JOHN, enter hastily, from opposite sides.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Whát is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Alas! the poor old woman is taken ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: She is my sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Your sister! (she assists Madame Moreau, who recovers slowly)

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: How Mademoiselle Philippine?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Yes, good old man, thou and I have often wept her loss:—rejoice! we have her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (holds out her hand to John) My good John, art thou still living?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Ay! why should I not? and your god-child is also alive?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dear Madam, shall I conduct you into the house? you will there be more comfortable.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: No, dear child:—the fresh air, and the sight that now enlivens me, are the best restoratives.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: If our affection thus revives thee—O! why didst thou not sooner return to our arms?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P:
Forgive me brother: forgive me, my good parents: often when I gathered resolution to surmount my shame, fate threw insurmountable difficulties in my way—I hastened with my husband from hence to his birth-place—Lyons—his parents were exasperated, they had other objects in view for him, and rejected us—
we determined to await from the soothing hand of time some favourable change in our destiny, and with the slender pittance of a friend, we embarked for America.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: To America! dare I inquire in what town you settled?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: In Charles-Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Gracious God! (she stands by Madame Mo∣reau, surveying her with the most fixed attention and anxiety, but unperceived by Madame Moreau.)

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: My husband's industry maintained us spa∣ringly—but we loved, and were content—heaven blest our union with two dear babes, a son and a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: What! a daughter?—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Where is she?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Ah, William, do not ask: it pleased heaven to punish me for the sorrow, I had occasioned my pa∣rents.—the war in which America contended for her independence, reduced us to poverty—we returned to Europe eight years since—we found only my husband's mother living—but she soon after died—we enjoyed a momentary repose till the terrible revolution destroyed our tranquility—my husband became a zealous patriot, and fell a sacrifice to avarice and anarchy—my son, mis∣guided young man, emigrated with some young dissi∣pated noblesse—Alas! they have but too well succeed∣ed, in having fashioned him into a vain self-conceited coxcomb, and eradicated every sense of nature and filial duty—I blush to own—he was the first who met me near the city gates.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: This city?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Yes, he is here—I recogniz'd him—not a glimmering of doubt remains to comfort me—with a groupe of riotous companions he rode past me:—my son! I exclaimed, and fell on my knees—he knew my voice—he threw a hasty look at me—I saw the blood rushing to his cheeks—the bridle trembled in his hand.—I heard one of the set enquire, who is that?—I stretch'd out my arms and sighed, I am his mother!—alas! he was ashamed of his kneeling parent.—The good woman, has lost her senses, said he, and gave his horse the spur.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Poor sister!—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Good God! can'st thou suffer such a weed in thy beautiful garden?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: I revere the avenging arm of providence—when from a far I perceived my paternal roof, the consciousness of my own undutifulness overcame me, and lo! God sent my son in my way, to exemplify the thankless child:—I do not complain—it is just:—who forsakes father and mother comes to a childless old age.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But thy daughter!—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: She died a miserable death!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (eagerly) She died!—where?—when?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Must I also relate that mournful event?—The British and Hessians stormed Charles-Town—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (wild) The Hessians!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Proceed, dear sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: One dreadful night, the town was fired and plundered—all fled—I clung to my husband, who car∣ried our daughter in his arms—the boy ran by our side—scarce had we reached the door—when my hus∣band fell by a musket shot:—in the same instant, a throng passed thro' the narrow street, and threw me senseless to the ground—after wandering alone for two days in the woods, I found my husband, but my Emma was lost!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Emma—in God's name—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: What means this?—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (with a faultering voice) Sister, this young lady is also named Emma, and after the storming of Charles-Town, was discovered among the smoaking ruins!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Brother!—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Hast thou any mark to recognize thy daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: None but my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Her age at that period?—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Eight years—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Her linen mark'd A. M.—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: (almost fainting) Amelia Moreau!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: It is her!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (falling on her bosom) My mother!

P.HI: (obs and wipes his eyes—The curtain drops.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. ERLACH enters in hasts—stops in the mid∣dle of the stage—appears to be considering—after a minute's deep thought, he raps his cane on the ground, as if he meant 'it shall be so,' and is going off—the Counsellor meets and stops him.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Whither? whither?—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Away!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What is amiss?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Nothing—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou art a singular being.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Accursed hour when I entered this house.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Do'st dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: No, I say no;—it is not my way, nor ever shall be.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What is it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Flaxland, hast ever seen a fool?—behold here stands one!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Singular being! what maggot has crept into thy head?—we have been seeking thee this hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Me! nobody seek me:—yes, well, if I were somebody—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: At length we espied thee in the meadow—marching with a quick step, backwards and forwards, and skirmishing with your hands—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That is nothing to any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I was hastening to tell thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I already know all.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Impossible!—the unhop'd discovery—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Silence!—I tell thee I already know all:—the girl is a bride—is she not?—with Herr von Hugel—is it not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Dost already know that?—it has but just now been told me!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: There we have it!—it is then true?—fare∣well!—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My God, whither wilt thou?—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Dost think I will be the laughing stock of the bridal feast? hey!—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My friend, I never saw thee thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I am too, for the first time in my life, a fool—but it has been of old my motro, to be nothing by halves. I am an entire fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: How can this connection concern thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Man, ask me not—orture me not—art thou so dull of comprehension that I must spell it to thee? why yes, I lately read to thee a chapter on false shame, and thou mayest retort upon me, that I am labouring under the same infirmity: Hear then, tho' the syllables be torn by pincers from my tongue; I—miserable wretch—I—the utterance will choak me! am in love! (he stops Flaxland's mouth) and now in God's name, hold thy tongue, hold thy tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou in love? ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach:
SP.P: There we have it; he laughs at me!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: No, I am truly sorry; had I but known it sooner—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou wouldst have overpersuaded the girl: blessings on the wedding feast; she shall never know it: and should a whisper escape thy tongue, thou and I must pull a trigger.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Who could ever imagine any thing like this—at thy age the infection is seldom catching!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Quite right!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: One should beware of being enslaved by one's own heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Proceed—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Better to pistol one self.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: May be—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Forgive this malicious raillery, and trust me, tho' I esteem Hugel as an excellent young man, I had rather have seen thee in his place.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Baby-pap!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But now let me tell thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I will know nothing! do me the favour to send for post-horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: How! thou wilt in good earnest—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Away!—and should'st thou peradventure know of some wilderness unhaunted by women, tell it me: (he looks about) Ah! now we have it—here she comes, with the little head drooping, lovelorn, and sentimentally, and I dare say, she will ask me my bles∣sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (Without turning, points his hand behind him)

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I see nobody but Emma.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why there!—Ah! brother—that the lass could not avoid being eight years older.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Did'st speak of her?—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Of whom else?—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Herr von Hugel's bride!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (peevishly) Why that I know too well already.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!—this is precious—dear Er∣lach, I leave thee alone with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (alone) The fellow is making game of me, so it goes,—we do but fall in love—and, lo! a storm of misery bursts upon us.—He leaves me alone with her: but does it follow, I will speak to her?—no!—I go my ways: farewell Mamselle—and should you again be buried up to the chin in soot—may I be damn'd—if—Erlach! Erlach!—one should not so the world be guilty of swearing—she comes nearer—What is that to me?—Should I go—she may con∣ceive I am running away from her.—No, no, Ma'm∣selle, it is not so dangerous as that neither—We will sit ourselves down in this arbour—may be, she is again on the look out for her somebody.—(He seats himself, and plays with his cane in the sand.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. EMMA and ERLACH.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P:
(enters, without perceiving Erlach, approach∣es slowly the linden trees—feelingly contemplates them—
throws both arms round one tree—, and exclaims, with emotion) Here, shed I the first tears of joy! God!—I thank thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (to himself with the chin resting on his cane) Ay, ay, it was here, where she first found him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: My Warmest wishes are fulfilled.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Warmest wishes—does that become a mai∣den?—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Happy days to come—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: That is the question!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: To —Is all I want.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And Erlach before every one.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (rising) I must find out the generous Erlach

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: My turn is come at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: How glad he will be.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (turning round discovers Erlach) Ah!—are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (drily, without changing his place) Here am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (playfully) You have been listening to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: It is not my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Do you already know?—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: O Yes!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Has the Counsellor told you that—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yes the Counsellor has told me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: But you do not partake in my happiness?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: O yes—why not?—I wish you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: So cold?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I cannot dissemble, and to speak plainly, I naturally expected earlier information.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Earlier!—how was that possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why did you send me away!—what pass'd between you, might be easily conceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I cannot comprehend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The way of the world—Friendship imprints her pretensions on the heart, as I do these letters on the sand:—a breath of love!—and all is obliterated.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Can my benefactor condemn this love?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: O! no!—What is it to me?—I have no voice in your election.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: My election!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: You love him—he is a deserving man—pru∣dent—in good circumstances—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: He! him!—What can this mean?—We misunderstand one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Not at all—the Counsellor informs me the business is settled with Herr von Hugel.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: O, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Well then?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: What is that to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What is it to you? that is curious.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I have been brought up with Minna; we love one another as sisters; and so far do I rejoice at her good fortne.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Minna! what has she to do with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Why, she is the bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Are you making a joke of me?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: You convers'd with Herr von Hugel—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: In Minna's name.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And gave consent—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: For Minna.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Indeed! in good earnest? and the fervent gratitude you express'd at this tree—could mere friendship produce such transport? Blessed then be he who shares your love!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: How come you—to touch that string?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Most naturally; by my soul! I feel myself so surprised! but so much the better; the soldier, in the heat of the battle, forgets the danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dear captain, you speak in riddles.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: May be; say but a half word, and I will solve the riddle.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Your coldness, your reserve, your transport! it is well we are unobserved.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (playful) A third person might have charg'd you with the shame—of being—in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Shame!—yes, yes,—it is a shame at my years!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Rather say on your principles.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I forbid all ridicule.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: How should I presume—?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: To be ashamed of abandoning absurd notions—is false shame—in one word, have you not re∣mark'd—?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: How;—nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: A most unlucky affair has happened to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: To you!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Do but guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: How can I?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Try, for it will be harder for me to explain, than you to divine.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: If I were vain—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Well?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I should be apt to suspect—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: You will laugh—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: By my soul! I am in no laughing mood.—Well, what would you suspect, were you vain?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: That—but pray forgive me

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Be quick—I forgive all.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: That you are in love with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So!—at last it is out.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I permit you to laugh at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And I permit thee to be vain—do'st under∣stand me?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Vain only!—my benefactor's love would make me more proud than vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: And Mr. benefactor will profit as little by pride as by vanity—no more of this—I do not like it—if thou hast an idea of owing me any thing, let us ba∣lance accounts.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I, poor girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Ay, ay—who will not pay, pleads poverty—it is beautiful, good, sensible—but poor, poor—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: For what I am and have, thanks to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Baby-pap!—that is not the question—I see thou wilt not understand me—I am too old, plain for thee—speak out.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Why this sounds almost—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Like an offer of marriage—why so, now we are at length come to time and place.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (after a pause) You are marking this day, as the most memorable of my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So! how is that meant?—yes or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: I esteem you highly.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Nothing further.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: A female seldom acknowledges more—had you permitted me to give the word, you would 'ere now have known that within these few hours, a third person has claimed a share of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Share?—that is not my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: And you must nw address yourself to my mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: To your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Your friend's sister, who formerly emigrated with her husband to America—and there in one hapless night, lost house, home, and child.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Lost! how?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: The lamented child, whom a gallant soldier rescued from the smoaking ruins, is named Amelia Mo∣reau—it is her who delighted in your martial apparel—and since she could think and feel, has adored her noble∣minded deliverer. The man who rais'd me from the ashes, acted bravely, but peradventure, many a one in the same predicament, would have saved the weeping child from death, and abandon'd it afterwards to its fate;—but the man, who during eight years, has shar'd with me his slender appointment—O! for him, thanks are a poor return.—Praise and fame may reward heroic deeds, but the noblest actions are not always the most brilliant—a great sacrifice is more easily accomplished in one hour, than a thousand small sweet courtesies, du∣ring the space of eight years.

SP.SPEAKER: Elach.
SP.P:
(who, whilst she is speaking with animation,
gives various signs of impatience) Have you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Not yet, Captain Erlach—with innate feel∣ing) not yet friend—benefactor—brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Brother!—I understand—

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: No, you do not understand me!—If my af∣fections were entangled, I would sighing confess—generous man, pitty me, I cannot love you:—but thanks to God, my heart is unfettered—esteem and good will, friedship and gratitude—yes, these sensations are com∣bined into one, and that one is love.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: My girl!—Is that thy earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: With an Erlach, no preciptancy need be fear'd, neither was your proposal utterly unexpected—the nipping coldness with which you left me, when I sought and found Herr von Hugel, intimated to me, what perhaps you scarcely yourself imagined;—my heart throbb'd high at the idea, to recompense my bene∣factor, and the life which he preserved, to devote to the happiness of his life;—these flattering ideas excited hopes, wishes—and now dear Captain—without affec∣tation—without false shame:—if a heart, full of inno∣cence—a grateful confidence—and the endeavour to de∣serve you, can suffice, I shall most willingly become your bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P:
(Seizes overjoyed her hand) Girl! girl! what dost thou make of me? I could fall on my knees be∣fore thee, had I not so often fondled thee on my knee—here then stand I—would fain speak and cannot—and falter before a being, who, eight years ago, was no taller than this rose-bush;—but one word for all, thou art my wife, my dearest wife!—Why, let them laugh—ha, ha, ha! I too will laugh—see here, see here, and disguise your envy under feign'd smiles—go your way—she is mine!—Erlach returns to his country, and the alps shall reverberate his shouts—for never was his heart so full of ecstacy.—(Eagerly and playfully he takes her hand under his arm) Yes, my good girl, we will buy us a farm, an alpine cot, with the friendly sun-beams sporting on our soil, where aromatic roots exhale health, and the wild roses carelessly bloom like thy cheeks—
there will we mingle in the song, and dance of a true hearted peasantry.—Huzza! Erlach and his matchless wife. He lifts her up, and swings her round)

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dear Erlach, my mother approaches—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Whom? thy mother:—I had nearly for∣gotten the romance—and is it then true?—pardon me if I delay enquiring how all this hangs together?—it seems to me as if I were with Emma alone in the world, and had no concern with the rest of mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Let us beg her blessing!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Ay, ay! (he throws away hat and cane—takes Emma in his arms, and carries her to meet her mo∣ther half way.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. MADAME MOREAU, the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Your blessing mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dearest mother, this gentleman is my saviour, my benefactor, and if you consent—my husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Is this the noble-minded man, whom I have to thank for my life's last comfort?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Nothing! Nothing!—all is amply repaid—we have just finished our account current, and a consi∣derable balance appears in your favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: He courts me for his wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: God! so much joy in one day'—my bles∣sing is with thee, follow the impulse of your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (grasps Emma in his arms) Come hither! we have the mother's blessing, and if we march hand in hand piously and honestly thro' the world, who will dispute with us God's blessing?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Does my brother know?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Whence?—a little quarter of an hour since I knew it not myself. Bravo! Flaxland, my uncle!—In that quality, he may laugh at me with impunity, for the dutiful nephew must not murmur. Come, my dear Emma, let us take courage, and boldly look the laugh∣ers out of countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Why should we be ashamed?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I that have been two-and thirty years a sim∣pleton, and thou to have deem'd it worth while to con∣vert such a simpleton.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. As he is going off arm in arm with her, they suddenly meet Minna and Hugel, also arm in arm—both couple, without separating, front one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Who goes there?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: A good friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The parole.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Love and hymen.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Bravo!—all are in pairs—that is just my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: How Captain?—that did not use to be thy way.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Other times—other manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Matrimony is an old fashion'd custom, and truly you stand there with Emma like a bridegroom.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Lavater forgot the bridegroom's physiognomy—but a female recognizes it at the first glance.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Emma, Emma, who could believe that the man whose arm so cordially entwines thee, was only thy guardian?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Away with the guardian—she is my bride!—and now laugh! shout! I am arm'd against your raillery.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Indeed!—why little cousin, thou dost not open thy lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why should she?—she has said yes, and that suffices.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Often a word too much. How, dear aunt—have you consented?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why should she not consent? hey?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: A woman hater!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: So much the more glory for my Emma.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: A rough hewn soldier—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Heart of oak is also rough, but the tree spreads its shadow far and wide.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: He is ever scolding and blustering—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: God beholds the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Yes, because he can penetrate it—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: So can Emma; (with innate sensibility lay∣ing her hand on his breast) is it not so Emma? thou see'st my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Dear Erlach, it beats for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Ah me! my poor dear little friend is lost!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Let her prate.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: The gallant Captain is a second Caesar—he comes—sees—and conquers!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Have I then known him only since this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: But, he—thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Psha!—when a spark falls into a powder bar∣rel, it blows up in the twinkling of an eye.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Psha!—I did not know that men's hearts were powder barrels:—but to what cannot be undone, we must administer the utmost consolation▪ and as you have proceeded together to such extremes, this solemn salutation (curtseying) may intimate—that—no, no—that is not to the purpose:—Come hither dearest Emma (kisses and embraces her) hast thou understood me?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: (gives Erlach his hand) Captain Erlach, I am most heartily glad—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (shakes his hand) Why right! an Anglo. German greeting—this language I have learnt from ho∣nesty.—Well children, when shall be the wedding day?

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Methinks to-morrow.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Why not to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Within the month.—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: In about a year.—

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: Who shall decide?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Our good aunt.—

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Have a care child, I always take the part of the weakest.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: That means us girls.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: By no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: At least not as brides.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Ask my brother, and here he comes apropos.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. The COUNSELLOR and the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (runs to meet him) Papa, the western wind has brought an influenza into your garden—every thing pairs itself—every thing will marry.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: So much the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Our platonic—our growler—our woman hater.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Pleasant distinctions!—

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: For thirty years and upwards he has made his head an ice-cellar, and heaped frozen apothegma the one upon the other but you blue eyes have prerced the gloom—and lo! the ice is instantly melted.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: So much the better.—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Yes, my worthy uncle—if you have no ob∣jection.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My dear nephew, thou hast better luck than thou deservest.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The Spaniards embark for America, to find gold—I have brought from thence a precious treasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Why so silent, dear sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: I ought to rejoice in the scene before me, but alas! my son! my only son!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Your son?—how Emma, hast thou yet a brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: Would to heaven, I could call him brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Where is he? who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: No more of this? my heart bleeds:—tell it him, when you are alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Right sister—let us not cloud the present cheerful hour—I am glad to perceive it undisturbed by the swarm of loungers.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: Mamma feigned a head-ache, and the one vanished after the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Where is thy mother?—nothing here is want∣ing but her presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: She has retired into her closet.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Retired from us?—what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: My life upon it, nothing bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: She received me with the most heartfelt af∣fection—she appeared overjoyed at my unlooked for appearance:—providence, said she, rewards me before∣hand—but dear sister go—within an hour, I can most cordially welcome you—within an hour, I hope to shew myself deserving of this blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Incomprehensible!—enigmatical!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: What wilt thou give me to put three on the scent?

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VI. JOHN, the former.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: (sobbing) Ah! your honor, my good master!—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What ails thee?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: I have lived almost half a century in your service.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Well?—

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: When a lad, I rooted up the weeds long ere they shewed themselves—to be sure I was then so little, and stupid, that I oft' scraped up the primrose and left the weed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My good old fellow, that happens frequently to children of larger growth—but why weepest thou?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Because I am in danger to be myself thrown upon the muck-heap, like garbage:—and, is it not so your honor tho' no peach tree, I am no nettle in your garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Who molests thee?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Hitherto, to be sure, I am excepted—but when one tree after the other is felled, my turn must come at last—Monsieur Rosa, the Friseur—Master Beefstick, the Maitre d'Hotell—Signor Maccaroni, the cook—and Heer Wantman, the porter, are all dischar∣ged.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Aha!

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: One after the other is called in, receives his half year's wages, and must pack up his bundle—the little conceited French mam'selle is now within, and when she is dispatched, may hap my turn may come—Remember Sir, I am an aged tree, that will not bear transplanting:—besides, I have young scyons shooting up, and what is to become of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Be at ease:—thou hast carried me in thy arms—helped me to plunder many a bird's nest, and while I live, thy nest shall remain unruffled.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P:
A thousand thanks!—neither is it any spar∣row's
nest from which to protect the cherries with net∣ting.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But I cannot comprehend—

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Thou wilt soon comprehend—yonder comes thy incomparable wife—away! away! let's leave a clear stage; for a matrimonial scene approaches, which must not be performed before spectators:—come, let us see if the musicians have already had leave of absence? we must suspend the furlough, for I will dance to-day, tho' I were myself to grumble the tune. (he offers Madame Moreau his arm, the others follow.)

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: My old woman sits forlorn on the bleech and moistens the linen with her tears—I must home—must tell her: do not cry old one, so long as we live, we shall grow our vegetables in this garden.
SP.STAGE: [The Counsellor remains in a profound recerie and scarcely perceives he is left alone.]

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE VIII.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (in a neat plain morning dress—she si∣lently approaches the Counsellor, and lays her hand gently on his shoulder] So deep in the thought!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Ah! my love, I was thinking of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: And yet look so gloomy.—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thy countenance disperses every wrinkle—except those which are impressed by age.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Domestic happiness, gives even to old age an unwrinkled forehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Then I should resemble a young man.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I appeal to thy heart—thou deceivest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: How? dost thou discredit my love?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: No:—but something more than love is required to constitute a happy union.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: More than love?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Love adorns the spring of life, and mar∣riage it's summer:—but they who in dalliance neglect to sow the seeds of confidence, how can they expect in autumn to gather the fruit of domestic bliss.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (smiling) Wherefore this poetic effusion?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Poetry! Well then—poetry is the atten∣dant of truth, and must assist in decorating her mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: From thy mouth I prefer truth unadorned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Very gallant.—As thou art in the vein to compliment me, allow me to ask, how you like me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou art so simply, so neatly drest, thou lookest most lovely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Handsomer than usual?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Much handsomer in my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Why then art thou incessantly, lavishing upon me silks and taffeta?—Why dost thou constrain me to follow every whim of fashion?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thy round of visits is numerous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: But why must I keep up this round of visits?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: To add to thy amusements.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Who makes thee believe, that I find else∣where more amusement than in thy company:—this sim∣ple deshabille—O! I well know it becomes me better than a gala suit—this is wholly for thee my dear—mo∣dest, unassuming, (smiling) the dust of jealousy will not cling to these folds.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Jealousy!—I hope thou dost not think me tainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Why not? if thou lovest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: But my confidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Why even there it sticks:—Oh! my good man, thou dissemblest before me a confidence, and tormentest thyself in private with frightful chimeras—was I not then justified in asserting, that love alone did not suffice to make the marriage state happy?

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (confused) Thou wrongest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P:
No, no, I now all, and spare thee the confession—a painful wound must be healed, without too much use of the probe or the knife—suffer me only to add, it is thyself, who was ever engaging me in the great world—it is thyself, who kept open house or cox∣combs and parasites—who feared thy young wife would be vapoured in thy house—That was false discretion—
Whilst complying with thy desire abroad, evil dreams haunted thee at home—but thou wast ashamed of them, and that was false shame:—Man and wife should not even conceal their dreams from one another—a look would have been enough—I might perhaps have indulged a little laugh against thee—but should most cheerfully have offered a worthless sacrifice to thy peace of mind. Oh! how many a marriage union is destroyed, because the band of confidence was not tied heart to heart. How oft the torch of discord becomes unextinguishable, be∣cause husband or wife smothered the first spark.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Angelic woman!—forgive me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I forgive thee, but upon one condition—that thou wilt be pleased, henceforward, not to move a step without me; when thou writest, I will set by thee with my work-bag—and when thou hast finished, we will continue together.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Instead of punishing, thou art rewarding me, my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: O!—I have now thought of a punish∣ment:—thou preferrest the town, but I think the coun∣try most engaging—only once within three years, have we visited our farm—that is unnatural—and as a penance thou must linger there with me the whole summer.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Caroline!—this is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I cannot spare thee—and thou must moreover be satisfied with household fare, for I have dis∣charged our privileg'd poison-mongers.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou hast, I understand, made several oecono∣mical retrenchments.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: A complete revolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thou wilt thereby diminish thy pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: And thereby acquire my heart's content:—! man! must I also learn thro' a friend, that the luxuries thou wast daily recommending—the superfluity, in which thou madest me indulge, were purchased at the expence of thy peace of mind—that I was wronging thy children, to reward by the robbery every species of ennui.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Why surely Erlach—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Thank God, for sending him to my salva∣tion—without him, I should have been hurried to perdi∣tion, and awoke too late!—Thou wicked man!—that again was thy fault, the want of confidence;—in thy opinion, women were incapable of estimating the value of a worthy man, unless his hands were ever loaded with presents, like the subjects of an Eastern Potentate. Learn to know us better—a wife is prouder in an esti∣mable husband, than in a pair of diamond ear-rings—and prefers going unnoticed on foot, possessing her hus∣band's affection, than without it, attracting the eyes of a gaoing croud, in a dazzling phaeton.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (falls at her feet) Caroline!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (smiling) Dear Flaxland, I must for the first time remind thee, that thou art turn'd of forty—kneeling does not become thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I have indeed misjudged thee!—pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: (raises him and embraces him) It is past—e will retire into the country, shall we not? and in a few years, my dissipation will be recovered. Oh!—how many an establashment falls to ruin, because the husband is ashamed to disclose to his wife, the true state of his circumstances—my experience this day, has so innately convinced me of this melancholy truth, that were I now standing before a numerous assembly, I should extend my arms, and glowing with philanthro∣py, should address each father of family—Trust thy wife—thou totterest perchance on the brink of an abyss—confidence may save thee—banish false shame, this monster of vanity and arrogance!—trust thy wife, thy truest friend!—and thou wilt be rewarded with consola∣tion for the past, with advice and assistance for the future.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Wife! what a spirit gives utterance thro' thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: I should be a law-minded wife, if love and duty could not inspire me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P:
I ought to be ashamed, that a woman of five-and-twenty, should instruct a man of any mature years:—but this were again false shame▪ which shall be for ever banished from my bosom:—from this moment, thou like God, shall behold my heart's inmost thoughts—even
those, that shun the light of day, will I whisper in thy ear—and whenever a weakness would lurk concealed, the remembrance of his hour, shall draw it forth, for thy good natur'd merriment and forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: O! God! I thank thee?—it is accom∣plish'd—my husband is once more mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Thine for ever!—but dearest Caroline, do not imagine, that thro' deranged circumstances thou art compelled to bury thy youth in the country—my pro∣perty is yet ample.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Bury!—the enjoyment of nature and one's self, men call burying—well then, the nightingales shall chaunt our requiem.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My dear Caroline, thou art not familiariz'd with solitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Thro' conjugal affection, the wife adopts another mode of life, with the same facility she changes a fashion:—I few years since, I fancied only a large at cou'd become me, and the hats were never large enough to my mind—I now think this fashion frightful, and am only pleased with myself in the smallest hat—Thus will it be in this case—four weeks in the country, and a city life will appear like a large hat—and I never shall be able to comprehend how I could endure myself in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: So be it then, if this is thy desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Here hast thou my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: I embrace it with extasy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Domestic retirement shall be our delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: And peace, in the bosom of my beloved!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: In the arms of affection—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Season'd by friendship—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Embellish'd by nature—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Nearly lost, thro' false shame—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Thro' confidence restored—

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (folds her in his arms) And never more to be abandoned—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Never! never!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IX. ERLACH and the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: (indignant) Scoundrel?—whoever breaks his neck, shall be amply rewarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: What aileth thee, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Scarce could I refrain from flourishing my rattan about his ears.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Of whom art thou speaking?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Of the most accomplish'd Viscount de Mail∣lac, my racally brother-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (astonished.) Thy brother-in-law!

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The wretch has the honor to be Emma's brother, and is ashamed of his poor mother:—just now, with his usual impertinence, he skipp'd thro' the garden gate, when Madame Moreau perceiv'd him, she cried aloud—my son!—it was a voice, that might have melted flint—the puppy started, and seem'd alarmed—but impudence would not leave him in the lurch—he snuffled—the lady is mistaken—we shudder'd, and ex∣plained to him, every one in his way, how the matter stood—Emma called him brother, and I a swindler—meanwhile, the agitated mother with uplifted hands, seem'd anxiously expecting a filial token, to fly into his arms;—it was truly ever my wish, muttered the wretch, to be allied to the Flaxland family, but if this be the only alternative—And so he shrugg'd his shoulders, folded himself like a snake, and darted out of the gate:—I called after him, fellow—Among all the species of false shame, the most attrocious is, to be ashamed of one's poor parents, because one wants the resolution, to brave the miserable raillery of a few courtly mendicants.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: My poor sister!—where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: The girls are endeavoring to dry her tears—here she comes—behold, how quickly a mother's af∣fliction bleaches the cheeks!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE X. MADAME MOREAU, HUGEL, MINNA, EMMA, and the former.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: (meeting her) My good sister!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P:
I beseech thee, brother, do not mention him—let no one name him more:—you could not but con∣demn
him—and his mother could not attempt his de∣fence. It is far gone indeed, when maternal affection must be silent! Ah! had he died in the cradle, I might have exclaimed, death has robb'd me of a lovely boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Emma.
SP.P: (caressing her) You have yet two children.

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: The lost chil is always the most lamented.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: We, must not expect cloudless days!

SP.SPEAKER: Moreau.
SP.P: Forgive me, I will not murmur; God has been to-day so indulgent to me! Ah! what was I, but a few hours past? Come to my arms, my dearest chil∣dren! (she embraces Erlach and Emma, and drops her head on her daughter's bosom)

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: I pledge you my hand, mother, I will re-in∣state you the boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: What is it I see? our woman-hater con∣verted?

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: These sudden convertites are not always the most secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach
SP.P: Miss Wisdom, learn from me, that from all proverbs and sayings, love is ever excepted.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: But after having so often vowed eternal ha∣tred to the sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Hugel.
SP.P: To the sex, but not to angels.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Well said, my good coz.

SP.SPEAKER: Minna.
SP.P: (to Hugel) Sweet Sir, it is written, you must have only eyes for me:—if this applies to the green bidal sapling, what must not one expect from the mature season'd wedding tree?—Take my father as an example—he is no longer a youngster—has been three years married, and behold how his eyes dwell enamoured on my mother!

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: Emulate her example—she has to-day made me the happiest of men!—Rejoice, Erlach, we remove into the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Flax.
SP.P: Thank him, my dear Flaxland.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P: Hush!—do not betray me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flax.
SP.P: A friend thanks not with words.

SP.SPEAKER: Erlach.
SP.P:
Cheerly my hearts!—here is a happy group—an angel would not blush to descend among us—your
ears have been regaled this morning with many a ditty—now, to please me, you must all join in the song—strike up musicians—joy!—planet of paradise!—Ely∣sum's child!

The music behind the scenes, plays Schillers Ode to joy, Flaxland takes his wife under the right, and his Sister under the left arm, joined on one side by Erlach and Emma, and on the other, by Minna and Hugel—Thus encircled, they sing:
SP.L: Ye, who in life's lottery blest,
SP.STAGE: The Curtain drops, and the sounds die gradually away.
